column5: Gordon Lightfoot . I have seen Gord in concert four times. Never get tired of Gord, like I do the others . I do like the 60s and 70s country . Dad played country all he time while I was growing up and I couldn't stand then , now I like it , go figure.
Good Point...I bet Jane and Neil would enjoy each others conversation very much.
Another Tragically Hip fan.
Can't believe no one listens to Da Yoopers!
Love to listen to TOOL when on the 502. Keeps my Moose googles clear.
YouTube school kids 46&2 cover. Pretty awesome! M our group usually BS till twin cities then whatever is on my iPod or XM
I'LL BE THE 5TH TO SAY THE TRAGICALLY HIP. nautical disaster, wheatkings, long time running ......

I like the old school Johnny Cash, "Tennessee Flattop Box," "Folsom Prison Blues," "Don't Take Your Guns to Town." Actually, any classic country from the 60's and 70's is my choice of Canada music. Classic Country on Sirius XM is my choice once we get across the border.I do like the Gordon Lightfoot stuff, too. 83 days till Larus Lake!!!

I made a Canadian music CD that is mandatory listening as soon as we cross the border in Fort Erie. Lots of Gord's Gold, tons of Neil, and Joni. It's become a ritual. Canadian Railroad Trilogy and Christian Island is music to my ears as we make our way up The Shield. Long may we run....

You guys should pick up Kim Mitchell's Greatest Hits.Go For A Soda/Patio Lanterns,they are all good.And yes,Gordon Lightfoot's music is Awesome.Oh I almost forgot,Trooper's We're Here For A Good Time(Not A Long Time)

As I bring the player, the folks going with me get to listen to traditional country the entire week we are up. I also bring most of the music, so the guys get to enjoy Amber Digby, Gene Watson, Vern Gosdin, George Jones, Patty Loveless, Emily Lou Harris, et al, and this year I've added my newest traditional country favorite Heidi Hauge. The boys staying up with cards play some newer country stuff. New folks to the group are warned ahead of time. For a long time, the trip started on the way up and on the way back with "On The Road Again" with Willie. Life is great, it doesn't get any better than this music!! Bill
Yep....great line. This thread got me in the mood for Gordon Lightfoot and I had it on Pandora all day today at work.

+1!! My Dad and his Dad were railroad men, so it's on the radio whenever Dad goes north. A little tribute to the heritage. Also, Willie and Waylon, Bob Seeger, some of the "b" side Garth Brooks stuff, Jerry Jeff Walker, and Jimmy Buffett. This year the old guy's gonna get "**** my Dad Says". Look that one up.

We have along list of tunes we listen to on the trip up north. Our favorite is East Bound and Down(Smokey and the Bandit) by Jerry Reed. Others include Amarillo by Morning by George Strait, Callin' Baton Rouge by Garth Brooks and Tennessee River Run By Darryl Worley.
Easy choice, Neil Young.
The Tragically Hip is my go to Canadian Band for fishing!!!
Corb Lund, a Canadian singer song writer.Not about fishing but still a good song.http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature...&v=EIWINsaEpnwhttp://corblund.com/albums/

Toby and Willie singing Beer for My Horses always reminds me of Canada. It was just out my first trip and got played over and over. Still makes it on the playlist now. Willie, Waylon, Johnny, mixed in with some new stuff and like Sin said, Crash Test Dummies get played each year too. I'm still waiting for LimeyAngler to bust out one of those songs in one of his videos. Sounds just like the guy!

Many of us Canadians are boycotting Neil Young after his ridiculous rampage earlier this year against Alberta oilsands . Sometimes these musicians and actors live in a pixy land where the economy and all its jobs don't run on fossil fuels. Earlier in this thread someone mentioned Don Charbonneau out of Wawa.......I bought a CD of his last year, great Canadian topics in his music. ............and Neil Young can take his music elsewhere.

I am not from Canada but I couldnt agree more on Neil Young. Music, much like fishing gear, is all personal preference so I dont want to come across as bashing something that others on here enjoy, but Neil Young's political rhetoric has been tiresome to me for as long as I can remember.
Could be worse... you could have Hanoi Jane.
I can't believe nobody has mentioned the greatest song writer of all time...Bob Dylan himself. Although he's not from Canada, he is a man from the Great White North.
Ya, but Duluth is close enough that we can consider it pseudo-Canadian ...
Dylan was from Hbbing and he hated living there.
Another for T-Hip!
John Prine for me. Fish & Whistle, and Lake Marie over and over and over............................................
When we hit 502 it's time for Canadian Railroad Trilogy (The railroad song) by Gordon Lightfoot, followed by Carefree Highway.

I always think of crossing the big bridge in Deluth MN when I hear "The wreck of the Evan Fitzgerald". The first time I ever heard that song was crossing that bridge. On another note (haha) "Southern Cross" whether it be by CSN or Jimmy Buffett always makes me think Lake Erie and Put in Bay. Strange I know.

On my first trip to Canada, my grandfather had an old 8-track of Waylon that he played over and over. Now, as soon as we clear the Soo, I pop on Waylon's greatest hits and enjoy the amazing views of Lake Superior. It really takes me back.

I agree with the Gordon Lightfoot comments....can't ever go wrong with putting his music on and letting it ride....However, not real sure about listening to him sing about the Edmund Fitzgerald right before launching a boat onto huge Canadian waters.....Man, thats a great tune though!
I always get a little shiver when he gets to the line "When afternoon came it was freezing rain in the face of a hurricane west wind" A simple lyric but it makes me almost feel like I was there.

Try this guy , he is a guide out of Wawa Ont. when he sings about walleye fishing or just being up north....I feel it...Part of our music library on the long ride up every June. http://www.doncharbonneau.com/group-of-7
Our trips the radio is off the whole time and the truck is filled with bs fish stories and hunting stories about the ones that got away. With the occasional burp and fart to lighten the mood!

When I'm on the 400 north of Toronto headed to the French River. I always have the greatest three man Rock & Roll band on."Start a new chapter Find what I'm after It's changing every day The change of a season Is enough of a reason To want to get away Quiet and pensive My thoughts apprehensive The hours drift away Leaving my homeland Playing a lone hand My life begins today" ~Rush http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HraQ00qbZ94
Rush, Gordon Lightfoot, Triumph, Bryan Adams and a CD of Voyager songs we bought at Fort William many years ago. I keep it Canadian after we cross the border Blair
Justin Bieber's first album.... Joking, joking!
Yeah. I prefer his early work, before you went commercial.

Anything by Gordon Lightfoot... (I have an awesome Gordo collection) the song "Whispers of the North" starts with loons calling! The Guys and I also play the "Last of the Mohicans" song. and Brad Paisley's "I'm Gonna Miss Her", but my wife hates that one.
Its Blackhawk for our group, their self titled album
Lots of Willie and Emmy Lou Harris. Then to enhance the Canadian ambience, lots of k.d. lang and Stompin' Tom Connors!
Speaking of K.D., this older interview of her in Australia shows some of her awesome talent... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Or-0aIHtD2Q

There's nothing like an old forgotten song to conjure up memories or emotions. What's your go-to song, singer, group that puts you in a Canadian mood? For me, it's Gordon Lightfoot. On the occasions when I used to drive north by myself, I used to drop in Gord's Gold and I'd practically be in International Falls by the end of the two CD set. By that time, I would definitely be in the mood for something a little more powerful yet still Canadian, so I'd drop in some Rush to cleanse the acoustic from my brain. Whenever I'm flipping the radio stations and come across a GL tune, I can't help but to think about heading north. This morning, my wife asked me if I wanted a "Second Cup of Coffee", and that got me started. I had to fire up "Song for a Winter's Night" and "Alberta Bound" to keep the mood going. Now I'm all mellowed out. I'd better get Geddy Lee screaming in my ear or I'll never get off the couch today.

[QUOTE=Carnhzkr;2503202] For me, it's Gordon Lightfoot. On the occasions when I used to drive north by myself, I used to drop in Gord's Gold and I'd practically be in International Falls by the end of the two CD set. Outstanding choice. "if they had put a couple more hours behind her, they would have made Whitefish Bay" Although not Canadian bands, Boston, Willie Nelson and Neil Diamond have always made the trips.... PjShorthorn

My best fishing buddy and BIL constantly sings "Dock of the Bay" while in Canada, complete with the whistling. over and over again and I join in with him...we never get tired of it. In fact if you checked out our video, you will hear the Percy Sledge version and see "Doc" We named him after the tune. Careful tho, this video is not good for your Cabin Fever. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rY9Et...ature=youtu.beOur "Go To" traveling music is Bob Seger and Stevie Ray Vaughn, along with a variety of good blues music. We make fun of the Bee boppy Canadian music we get on the radio while in Canada, but we tolerate it as a critical part of the trip.When we get rained on, we will break out into some Leon Russell "Hard Rain, Gonna fall" and Eagles songs always seem to fit.Most of us are children of the 60's, so we are rockers at heart!
Alberta Bound always gets a play on our trip (even though we go to Ontario). "It's good to be Alberta Bound"
I just jam on Sirius XM all the way.As I can always find songs that keep me awake,Bill

I Like the Brooks and Dunn Song "Good Time" I always rewrite the lyrics and incorporate Canada and fishing. Kinda fun. And The Fishin Song, anything by ZZ Top, BTO, Led Zeplin, Steve Miller Band etc. And we ALWAYS listen to a "Rodney Carrington" CD to get unsustained laughter and tears. The trip up is great the trip home SUCKS!! Then its Michael Buble "I wanna Go home and all kinds of whiney *** crap. LOL Usually a quiet trip home.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uB85RY2Xk_U kid rock all summer long. Catching walleye from the dock........... Also, the old country stuff. Merle Haggard, Johnny Cash, Waylon BAck in the young days we flew in and drank in the boat (no we don't do that now) so fishing, drinking and the Crash Test Dummies. LOL

Well.... on the way Up, as I drive from Denver, I GOTTA have "mood music" I.E. Sirius XM.... OCTANE, OZZIES BONEYARD; HAIR NATION and LIQUID METAL; DEEP CUTS.... Keeps Me FOCUSED... When We get there... I let em play Elvis channel and all the Country stuff... The WALLEYES prefer it that way. So Do My Buddies....
Tragically hip
Anything by my favorite Canadian, Neil Young.
